Enhanced catalytic performance for aerobic dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles over bimetallic CoOX-CeO2 catalysts derived from Ce-based MOFs Zhixian Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Formal analysis Ruibi Zhao Validation Investigation Formal analysis Wenjing Li Validation Investigation Formal analysis Hao Sun Validation Investigation Formal analysis Guozhu Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision Fuxu Zhan Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Formal analysis Huaiqing Zhao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Resources Project administration Methodology Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong 250022, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering University of Jinan Jinan Shandong 250022 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong 250022, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. N-heteroaromatics as one of cornerstones in chemical processes are in the limelight, so the synthesis of N-heteroaromatics have been attracted a great deal of attention. Among the elegant methods for the preparation of N-heteroaromatics, the direct oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated compounds affording N-heteroaromatics is a simple and efficient tactic. In this work, CoOX-CeO2 composites synthesized by the pyrolysis of Co/Ce-BTC MOFs as the precursor were employed as a heterogeneous catalyst for the dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles under aerobic conditions. CoOX-CeO2 composites were analyzed by diversified characterization techniques of SEM, TEM, BET, XRD, XPS, and ICP-OES. The characterization results demonstrate that abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface and the synergistic effect of CoOX-CeO2 composites remarkably enhance the catalytic performance of CoOX-CeO2 catalysts. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of CoOX-CeO2 composites remained excellent after six recycles. This catalytic system provides an alternative tool for the effective synthesis of aromatic compounds. Graphic abstract CoOX-CeO2 composites as a heterogeneous catalyst for the aerobic dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles Image, graphical abstract Keywords CoOX-CeO2 composites Heterogeneous catalysis Oxidative dehydrogenation Metal-organic frameworks Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aromatic compounds are indispensable in modern society because of their high demand in chemical, food, rubber fabrication and pharmaceutical industries [1-3]. As one of important aromatic compounds in organic chemistry, indoles have been widely found in pharmaceutical molecules and bioactive natural products [4,5]. Because of the importance of indoles, it is of great significance for the development of the synthesis of indoles compounds. The classical methods of indole synthesis include Fisher indole synthesis [6], Bischler indole synthesis [7] and Bartoli synthesis [8], but there are some limitations such as the complicated reaction process, harsh reaction conditions and lower conversion [9]. Therefore, the limitations of these classical synthesis methods mean that it is still urgent to establish new strategies for the preparation of indoles. In recent years, a variety of methods for the synthesis of indoles such as transition-metal catalyzed the preparation of indoles has been developed [10,11]. Direct dehydrogenation from heterocyclic compounds is a simple and efficient tactic to afford N-heteroaromatics. However, the dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles is a thermodynamically “uphill process”, the reaction conditions are relatively harsh in some cases, such as high temperature, high pressure and highly active catalysts [12-14]. Until now, homogeneous catalysts have shown excellent catalytic activity in various dehydrogenation reactions [15,16], but it is difficult to be employed on large scale synthesis due to the difficulty of catalyst recovery, complex ligand synthesis and high cost. Meanwhile, it is strenuous to separate all of the metal catalyst from the products in the homogeneous catalytic system, which leads to metallic residues in the products. Therefore, homogeneous catalysts are limited in many fields, such as the application of life-science [17]. In comparison, heterogeneous catalysts have been widely studied and applied due to their simple separation process from the catalytic system and the recyclability. It is worth noting that acceptorless dehydrogenation and receptor assisted dehydrogenation are two types of dehydrogenation reactions with different heterogenous catalysts. Compared with the acceptorless dehydrogenation, the receptor dehydrogenation can effectively decrease the required thermodynamic energy barrier for the dehydrogenation process in the presence of oxidants, so it can be carried out under more milder conditions, such as lower temperature and pressure [18,19]. Stoichiometric oxidants such as DDQ and peroxides are commonly used in the oxidative reactions. However, such a process will produce stoichiometric wastes harmful to the environment [20]. In comparison, abundant, inexpensive and environmentally friendly molecular oxygen is undoubtedly the most attractive oxidant [21]. Therefore, molecular oxygen as a green oxidant in the oxidative dehydrogenation of N-heterocyclics has been introduced to promote the dehydrogenation process [22,23]. Recently, elegantly reported heterogeneous catalysts Au [24], Ru [25], Pd [26] and Pt [27] have been developed in the oxidative dehydrogenation of N-heterocyclics, but most of the reactions depend on precious metals. It is imperative to explore other metal catalysts to replace precious metals. As an abundant rare earth metal, cerium has been utilized to synthesize CeO2-based catalysis. The redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ and the existence of rich oxygen vacancies make CeO2 possess strong oxygen storage capacity, so it is conducive to the oxidation reactions [28,29], such as CO oxidation [30,31] and volatile organic compound oxidation [32,33]. The cheap metal cobalt derived CoO and Co3O4 are both stable oxides in various cobalt oxides. Among them, due to the relatively low enthalpy change of evaporation of O2, the strength of Co-O bond in Co3O4 is not strong, which will facilitate the desorption of more lattice oxygen [30,34]. Therefore, cobalt oxides have been exploited in oxidation reactions in various catalytic systems [30,35]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with high porosity, adjustable pore size, high specific surface area and diverse structure are widely investigated in the field of catalysis [36,37]. And we noted that MOFs can be used not only as a catalyst directly, but also as a template for the synthesis of porous nano-oxides by pyrolysis, which provides a promising strategy for the synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts [38]. Recently, our laboratory has also developed the catalytic oxidative reactions with CeO2 derived from MOFs as carries [39-41]. Given the advantages of CeO2 derived from MOFs and cobalt oxides in catalytic oxidation reactions, a highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst CoOX-CeO2 for the dehydrogenation reaction was designed and developed in our work. In this work, CoOX-CeO2 composites prepared by Co/Ce-BTC MOFs pyrolysis at 450 °C were developed as an efficiently heterogenous catalyst for the dehydrogenation with molecular oxygen as an oxidant. The experimental results show that the synergistic effect between CoOX-CeO2 composites is a crucial factor in the catalytic oxidation reaction. The recovery experiments show that the catalyst can be reused for six times, and the catalytic activity of the catalyst does not decrease obviously. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of catalyst The catalyst was synthesized according to the method reported literature [42]. 1.05 g H3BTC, 2.17 g Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and 0.1455 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O were dissolved in 50 mL ethanol and stirred fully. Then, the fully mixed solution was poured into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. After the samples were cooled to room temperature, the precipitate was collected by ultra-high speed centrifugation and washed three times with ethanol. The obtained sediment was placed in an oven and dried at 80 °C for 12 h, and finally cerium-based MOF was obtained, which was named Co/Ce-BTC. Then the solid was ground in agate mortar. When the obtained Co/Ce-BTC was put in a muffle furnace and calcined at 450 °C for 3 h, the obtained solid was CoOX-CeO2 (Fig. 1 ). 2.2 The procedure of catalytic reactions The oxidative dehydrogenation of indoline was selected as a model reaction to explore the catalytic activity of CoOX-CeO2 composites. Firstly, indoline (0.2 mmol), CoOX-CeO2 composites (3 mg) and CH3CN (2 mL) were added into a glass tube with inner diameter of 14 mm and 35 mL. Then, the rubber plug was installed on the glass tube, and the rubber plug was replaced by Teflon nut under the oxygen flow after three times of oxygen replacement. Finally, the mixture was reacted at 70 °C and stirred for 15 h. When the reaction was over, GC–MS was used to analyze the reaction mixture. 2.3 The recycling experiments of the catalyst The recovery experiments were carried out under the standard reaction conditions. When the reaction was completed, the mixture was transferred from the reaction tube to a 50 mL centrifuge tube. The reaction tube was cleaned with 2 mL CH3CN, and then CH3CN was also transferred to the centrifuge tube. The operation was repeated three times to ensure that the reaction liquid and heterogeneous catalyst were completely transferred to the centrifugal tube. After that, the heterogeneous catalyst was separated by centrifugation with a high-speed centrifuge. The supernatant was collected for GC–MS analysis. The separated catalyst solid was washed twice with anhydrous ethanol and then transferred to an oven at 80 °C to dry overnight. After that, the catalyst was weighed and the above operation was repeated. In order to ensure the accuracy of the experimental results, the amount of other reagents in the reaction system should be calculated according to the quality of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst Firstly, the crystalline structure of CoOX-CeO2 composites were explored by X-ray diffraction analysis. The peak position of the X-ray diffraction pattern of Ce-BTC MOFs shown in Fig. S1 at 8.45°, 10.6°and 18.4° (2θ) indicates that the Ce-BTC MOFs has the good crystallinity, which is consistent with the results of the related literature [43,44]. The XRD patterns of CeO2 derived from Ce-BTC MOFs and CoOX-CeO2 composites are shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peaks of CoOX-CeO2 composites by pyrolysis from Co/Ce-BTC are located at 28.67°, 33.2°, 47.3°and 56.4°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311) planes of CeO2 cubic phase respectively, which match the JCPDS card number (34–0394) [45]. After that, through the analysis of the XRD spectrum of CoOX-CeO2 composites, it is found that the position of the diffraction peaks is very consistent to that of CeO2 produced by Ce-BTC MOFs pyrolysis, and no obvious diffraction peak of CoOX was found. This may be due to the high dispersion of cobalt oxide or the low content of cobalt species relative to cerium [46,47]. Therefore, the high catalytic activity of CoOX-CeO2 composites as a heterogeneous catalyst may be related to the good dispersion of cobalt oxide [48]. In addition, compared with the CeO2 XRD diffraction peak, the position of the XRD diffraction peak of the CoOX-CeO2 composites did not shift, which indicated that cobalt oxide exists on the surface of the composites but not were embedded in the interior of the composites [45]. The morphology of Ce-BTC MOFs,Co/Ce-BTC and CoOX-CeO2 composites were studied by scanning electron microscope. As shown in Fig. 3 a, b, it can be clearly observed that the unpyrolyzed Ce-BTC MOFs has a rod-like appearance. With the addition of cobalt species, the morphology of Co/Ce-BTC becomes rough (Fig. 3 c, d). The SEM images of Co/Ce-BTC composites show that the morphology of MOF is destroyed with the addition of cobalt nitrate. After calcination in muffle furnace at 450 °C, the surface of the composites become rougher, but its morphology keeps rod-like morphology (Fig. 3 e, f). The rough surface may make CoOX-CeO2 composites possess larger specific surface area, which is more beneficial for the catalytic dehydrogenation. After that, the CoOX-CeO2 composites were characterized by transmission electron microscope (TEM), and its characterized appearance was consistent with that of scanning electron microscope (Fig. 4 a, b). High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images show the existence of Co3O4 nanoparticles and their crystallization in CoOX-CeO2 composites. As shown in Fig. 4 c, the ordered lattice fringes with interlayer spacing of 0.47 nm of Co3O4 species can be clearly observed, corresponding to the (111) plane of the Co3O4 crystal [49]. It is further demonstrated that Co species in the CoOX-CeO2 composites exist in the form of Co3O4. In addition, there are lattice fringes with layer spacing of 0.31 nm in HRTEM images, which can well correspond to the (111) crystal plane of CeO2 [50]. However, we did not observe more crystal planes of Co3O4 when analyzing lattice fringe in HRTEM images, which may be due to the compression strain generated from the close interface contact between Co3O4 and CeO2 nanoparticles (Fig S2) [51]. The distribution of Co and Ce species on the catalyst surface can be clearly observed through high angle annular dark field mapping (HAADF) images and EDS mapping images (Fig. 5 ). The results show that Co species are uniformly distributed on the surface of CoOX-CeO2 composites, which is beneficial to the storage and activation of molecular oxygen, and thus conducive to the catalytic oxidative dehydrogenation reaction [52]. According to the elemental mappings, the content of Co in CoOX-CeO2 composites is 0.25 wt% (Fig S3, Table S1). Although the loading amount of Co in the sample can be roughly obtained by EDS, the test results are not accurate due to the limitation of the observation range. Therefore, the CoOX-CeO2 composites were further characterized by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), and the more accurate Co content is 0.77 wt% (Table S2). N2 adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out to evaluate the specific surface area, pore diameter and pore volume of CoOX-CeO2 composites, Co/Ce-BTC and Ce-BTC MOFs. As shown in Fig. 6 , the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of all samples show obvious IV adsorption isotherms and type H3 hysteresis loops [53,54]. It can be seen from the pore size distribution of Fig. 6 and Table 1 that these three materials are all mesoporous materials [55]. Compared with Ce-BTC MOFs, the introduction of Co species significantly improved the adsorption capacity of the material and changed the surface area and pore structure of Co/Ce-BTC MOFs. This indicates that the addition of Co(NO3)2·6H2O alcohol solution has an etching effect on Ce-BTC MOFs, which is more conducive to exposing more active centers [39,56,57]. The specific surface area and pore volume of CoOX-CeO2 composites obtained by Co/Ce-BTC pyrolysis are further increased, which was mainly due to the volatilization of unstable substances in MOFs [58]. At the same time, the collapse of MOFs skeleton due to pyrolysis may cause pore diameter changes [59]. The catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalyst is related to its specific surface area. The larger the specific surface area, the more active centers can be exposed, so the catalytic activity of catalyst could be improved [60]. The surface chemical properties of CoOX-CeO2 catalysts were further analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 7 ). XPS analysis show that Ce, Co, C and O elements are present in the catalysts. The analysis of Ce 3d spectra shows that there are six groups of peaks with binding energies of 916.7 eV, 907.3 eV, 901.2 eV, 898.5 eV, 889.0 eV and 882.5 eV, indicating the presence of Ce4+ (Fig. 7 b) [61]. At the same time, there are four groups of peaks with binding energies of 905.8 eV, 899.1 eV, 885.4 eV and 881.5 eV, indicating the existence of Ce3+. Since Ce4+ is stable, the positive charge reduced by Ce3+ can be compensated by the oxygen vacancy, so the presence of Ce3+ can be used as the evidence of the existence of the oxygen vacancy [62-64]. As shown in Fig. 7 c of the O 1 s spectrum, there are two peaks with binding energy of 529.3 eV and 531.6 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (OLattice) and oxygen vacancy (Ovacancy) [61,65,66]. Through the analysis of O 1 s XPS spectrum, it is found that there are oxygen vacancies, and the abundant oxygen vacancies play a key role in the catalytic oxidation. In order to understand the state of its existence, the XPS spectrum of Co was analyzed (Fig. 7 d). In the Co 2p spectrum, there are two peaks with binding energies of 780.5 eV and 779.5 eV corresponding to Co 2p3/2 spectra, belonging to Co2+ and Co3+, respectively [67]. The peak at 788.0 eV is attributed to the satellite peak [68]. The Co 2p XPS peak confirmed the existence of Co2+ and Co3+ valence states in CoOX-CeO2 composites. According to relevant literature, the presence of mixed valence states of Co2+ and Co3+ is beneficial to oxidation [19]. Abundant oxygen vacancies and the existence of metal ions with variable valence states make CoOX-CeO2 composites can be utilized as a heterogeneous catalyst for oxidative dehydrogenation. 3.2 The optimization of the catalytic reaction conditions In this work, the catalytic activity and optimum reaction conditions of CoOX-CeO2 catalyst were investigated with a model reaction of the oxidative dehydrogenation of indoline. The corresponding dehydrogenation product indole was not obtained with an ideal yield with CoOX-CeO2 composites as a catalyst and molecular oxygen as an oxidant (Table 2 entry 1 and Table S3). According to the previous works [69,70], we noted that N-hydroxyphthalimide (NHPI) is helpful to activate oxygen when molecular oxygen is utilized as an oxidant in organic reactions. Thereupon, NHPI was introduced to the aerobic dehydrogenation of indoline as an additive. The anticipated dehydrogenation product indole was afforded by using H2O as a solvent, oxygen as an oxidant and NHPI as an additive with a yield of 9 % (Table 2, entry 2). Then try to explore other different solvents, the results show that CH3CN is the better solvent and the yield of indole can reach 98 % at 90 °C (Table 2, entries 3–7). The reaction yield could still remain 98 % even if the reaction temperature lowers to 70 °C. Nevertheless, the reaction yield was decreased to 52 % when the reaction temperature was dropped to 60 °C (Table 2, entries 8–9). Next, the effect of catalyst dosage in the reaction was investigated. The experimental findings demonstrate that the catalyst dosage would alter the reaction and the ideal dosage of catalyst is 3 mg with 0.2 mmol scale of indoline (Table 2, entries 10–11). Subsequently, the amount of NHPI was also surveyed and 20 mol% is the better dosage (Table 2, entry 12). The effect of the reaction atmosphere was very obvious when the reaction was carried out in air (Table 2, entry 13). Trying to shorten the reaction time to 14 h, the reaction yield was reduced and the conversion of substrate was not complete (Table 2, entry 14). After that, we investigated the influence of cobalt content on the catalytic activity of CoOX-CeO2. The experimental findings showed that the optimal Co content was 0.77 wt% (Table S4). In order to verify the importance of the catalyst in the catalytic system, a series of control experiments were conducted. The product yield decreased significantly when CeO2 or Co3O4 was utilized alone as a catalyst (Table 2, entries 15–16). In addition, we also used Co/Ce-BTC as a catalyst, but the reaction could not provide indole in a satisfactory yield (Table 2, entry 17). Simultaneously, we investigated the catalytic performance of other catalysts in this transformation (Table S5). According to the experimental results, the CoOX-CeO2 composites produced via MOFs pyrolysis exhibit the better catalytic performance. It is also verified that the synergistic effect of CoOX-CeO2 composites contributes to an increase in catalytic activity. We also synthesized other CoOX-CeO2 composites with various Ce based MOFs; the results of the reactions with other CoOX-CeO2 as catalysts indicate that BTCCoOX-CeO2 is the better catalyst in this transformation (Table S6). 3.3 Substrate scope With the optimal reaction conditions, the scope of application of CoOX-CeO2 catalytic system was exploited in Table 3 . Firstly, we noted that indoline and its derivatives with electron-donating substituents on the benzene ring can be converted to corresponding dehydrogenation products in 86–99 % yields (Table 3, entries 1–4). In comparison, the yields of indolines with the electron-withdrawing nitro and bromine group on the benzene ring were lower (Table 3, entries 5–7). Notably, the yield of 5-nitroindole could reach 75 % when the nitro group was at the 5-position of indoline. However, when the nitro group was at the 6-position of indoline, the reaction furnished 6-nitroindole in only 14 % yield. We also tried to adjust the reaction temperature, but the reaction was not able to afford the product in a better yield. It indicated that the position of substituents on the benzene ring will impact the dehydrogenation of heterocycle. Subsequently, the dehydrogenation of 1-(indolin-1-yl)−2-methylpropan-1-one was performed, but the corresponding dehydrogenation product was not observed (Table 3, entry 8). The result showed that the existence of NH bond was a vital unit to the dehydrogenation reaction of N-heterocycles, which was consistent with the results reported by Liu and his colleagues [71]. At the same time, we also investigated the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and its derivatives in this catalytic system, and the desired dehydrogenation products can also be obtained. Compared to indole compounds, the reactions generally require longer reaction times or higher reaction temperatures. For instance, the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline could furnish quinoline in 80 % yield when the reaction temperature was raised to 100 °C and the reaction time was prolonged to 28 h, (Table 3, entry 9). As shown in Table 3, 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline and its derivatives with OMe, Br and Me groups can be transformed into the corresponding products in good to excellent yields (Table 3, entries 10–13). Furthermore, under the standard conditions, anthracene, isoquinoline, and quinoxaline can be synthesized (Table 3, entries 14–16). It is interesting to noted that the oxidative dehydrogenation of 1,2-dihydronaphthalene was still challenging, the result suggested that the presence of nitrogen atom may play a critical role in the dehydrogenation reaction (Table 3, entry 17). 3.4 Time-dependent and recycling experiments of CoOX-CeO2 In order to assess the dynamic changes in the reaction system over time, a kinetic profile experiment of indoline was conducted. As shown in Fig. 8 a, several different reaction times were selected to test and analyzed the reaction. The kinetic curve clearly demonstrates a rapid increase of indole as the reaction time progresses. The yield of indole quickly reached 80 % in 8 h, but the conversion of indoline gradually slow down after that. In addition, the catalyst was taken out from the reaction when the reaction proceeded for 2 h. And then the content of indole almost did not increase when the reaction solution without catalyst lasted for 12 h (Fig. 8 b). These results indicate that CoOX-CeO2 is crucial for the oxidative dehydrogenation in this heterogenous catalytic system. The recovery and reuse experiments were conducted to investigate the catalytic activity and stability of CoOX-CeO2. Indoline served as the substrate for the catalyst recovery and reuse reactions. The catalyst can be recycled for six times with a negligible decrease in the catalytic performance ( Fig. 9 a, Table S7). The recovered catalyst was characterized by SEM, XRD, XPS and FT-IR. The results show that the morphology, metal valence and structure of the recovered catalyst have not changed significantly (Fig. 9 b-f, Fig. S4). By comparing the Co 2p XPS spectra, it was found that the ratio of Co3+ in the catalyst changed from 0.73 % to 0.65 % (Fig. 9 e). It indicates that the stability of CoOX-CeO2 catalyst is outstanding. 3.5 Mechanism experiments To clarify the detailed process of the oxidative dehydrogenation in this catalytic system, a series of control experiments with 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (9a) were carried out (Scheme 1 ). Initially, when CoOX-CeO2 and NHPI were removed from the system, the yield of quinoline (9b) was significantly reduced (Scheme 1, (a) and (b)), which indicated that they are necessary for the achievement of this reaction. Subsequently, 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-N-oxyl (TEMPO) and 2,6-ditertbutyl-4-methyl-phenol (BHT) were respectively added into the reaction system as a free radical scavenger, and the yield of quinoline was also greatly decreased. These findings showed that a free radical process may be involved in the oxidative dehydrogenation reaction (Scheme 1, (c) and (d)). Ultimately, the reactions were carried out under different atmosphere to confirm the significance of oxygen in the system (Scheme 1, (e) and (f)). The reaction generated quinoline in only 35 % yield under air, and there was the trace amount of quinoline under nitrogen. The results showed oxygen was vital to obtain the dehydrogenative product in this catalytic process. It is well accepted that reactive oxygen species (ROS) are usually produced with the oxygen activation. And the ROS mostly consist of superoxide radicals (O2 •−), singlet oxygen (1O2) and hydroxyl radicals (•OH) [72]. Therefore, we performed control experiments with a variety of scavengers in order to better clarify ROS in the reaction system, (Fig. 10 ). The dehydrogenation yield of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (9a) dropped to 40 % when furfuryl alcohol (FFA) was added to scavenge singlet oxygen (1O2), suggesting that 1O2 was generated in the reaction [73]. And then 1,4-benzoquinone (BQ) was added to the reaction system as a superoxide radicals (O2 •−) scavenger, and the reaction was completely suppressed, indicating that O2 •− was a significant reactive oxygen species in the reaction [73,74]. Ultimately, the reactions with the addition of tert‑butyl alcohol [75] and mannitol [76] as hydroxyl radicals (•OH) scavengers can provide quinoline in yields of 79 % and 75 %, respectively, which indicated that •OH has a slight influence on the reaction. According to the above results, reactive oxygen species (ROS) such as 1O2 and O2 •−are involved in the catalytic dehydrogenation with CoOX-CeO2 as a catalyst. Based on the relevant research and the results of our experiments, a possible mechanism was proposed [77-80]. Initially, the adsorbed molecular oxygen could be activated to O2 •− over CoOX-CeO2 catalysts, which then took part in oxidative dehydrogenation. Subsequently, O2 •− was transformed to H2O2, meanwhile, NHPI was converted to PINO radicals [81]. And then 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroquinoline (9a) and PINO radicals underwent a single electron transfer (SET) process to generate the radical cation Ⅰ and NHPI anion. The imine intermediate II was subsequently afforded with the reaction of the intermediate I and NHPI anions via the single electron transfer (SET) and proton transfer (PT) over CoOX-CeO2 catalysts in the path A. Soon afterwards, the isomerization of II occurred to produce III and IV. Ultimately, quinoline (9b) was obtained by the catalyst-assisted dehydrogenation with H2O2 as an oxidant, which was accompanied by the production of water (path A). On the other path, the singlet oxygen (1O2) was formed from O2 •− over the catalyst surface [82]. And then the achieved singlet oxygen could abstract two H atoms from I to provide II and H2O2 [83]. The similar process in path A was followed to afford quinoline (9b) (path B) (Scheme 2 ). 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed an effective method that employs a heterogenous CoOX-CeO2 catalyst to achieve the oxidative dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles. CoOX-CeO2 composites were prepared by the pyrolysis of Co/Ce-BTC MOFs. The catalytic system was applied to the dehydrogenation of a broad scope of substrates with molecular oxygen as an oxidant and NHPI as an additive to afford various aromatic compounds. The characterization results of CoOX-CeO2 composites and the mechanism experiments indicate that abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface and the synergistic effect of CoOX-CeO2 composites are responsible for the remarkable catalytic activity of the heterogeneous catalysts, the introduction of NHPI as an additive could be conducive to the dehydrogenation process in this catalytic system. More importantly, CoOX-CeO2 composites have an excellent recycling performance and can be reutilized six times without notable loss of catalytic activity. Hence, the catalytic system of CoOX-CeO2 composites could be employed as an effective dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles as a complement to existing dehydrogenative methods. coredata.dc:description: N-heteroaromatics as one of cornerstones in chemical processes are in the limelight, so the synthesis of N-heteroaromatics have been attracted a great deal of attention. Among the elegant methods for the preparation of N-heteroaromatics, the direct oxidative dehydrogenation of saturated compounds affording N-heteroaromatics is a simple and efficient tactic. In this work, CoOX-CeO2 composites synthesized by the pyrolysis of Co/Ce-BTC MOFs as the precursor were employed as a heterogeneous catalyst for the dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles under aerobic conditions. CoOX-CeO2 composites were analyzed by diversified characterization techniques of SEM, TEM, BET, XRD, XPS, and ICP-OES. The characterization results demonstrate that abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface and the synergistic effect of CoOX-CeO2 composites remarkably enhance the catalytic performance of CoOX-CeO2 catalysts. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of CoOX-CeO2 composites remained excellent after six recycles. This catalytic system provides an alternative tool for the effective synthesis of aromatic compounds.

coredata.dc:title: Enhanced catalytic performance for aerobic dehydrogenation of N-heterocycles over bimetallic CoOX-CeO2 catalysts derived from Ce-based MOFs
